    This is a graded discussion: 20 points possible

    due Mar 16
    Due For Available from Until
    Mar 16 Mar 16 at 11:59pm Everyone Mar 7 at 12am Mar 7 at 12am May 20 at 11:59pm May 20 at 11:59pm
    Click to change profile picture for Josh Scanlan

    Week 9 Discussion: Framing and Reframing

    Josh Scanlan
    Mar 9 at 1:57pm
    171 171 unread replies. 171 171 replies.

    This week we launch the exploration of the problem spaces each of your teams is exploring.  You will do a combination of interviewing and online research to explore that space.  The readings for this week set you up to frame and reframe the problem you are tackling by viewing it as a system, and by doing interviews to learn more about it from others.

    As you watch the "Simplifying Complexity" video, read the "Frame and Reframe" article, and skim the materials in "Talking with Humans" and "Note on Observe" think about the system in which your problem sits.  (You may find the additional reading from "Thinking in Systems" helpful as well.)  For this week's discussion:

    • State the "how might we?" question on which your team is focused to start.
    • Describe what you think the core elements of the system that sits around that "how might we?" are
    • Ask two questions of your classmates about things in that system that you don't yet fully understand

    Post your response and help out two of your classmates with their system questions.

     

    This topic was locked May 20 at 11:59pm.
    This topic was edited by William Collins
    Filter replies by unread Show deleted replies

        Collapse Subdiscussion Lal Altuner

        Lal Altuner

        Mar 9, 2017 Mar 9 at 5:48pm
        Our “how might we?” question is “How might we teach basic life skills to ensure independence and increase people’s awareness on this topic?”   Think about your life in high school. You are living with your family, you don’t have great responsibilities, your mom cooks for you and your dad pays your bills. Then, you start to college. You move to a home with your friends. You have to do your own laundry, you have to make your bed, you have to pay your bills, you have to set a bank account, you have to cook yourself.   When we think about these basic life skills, we see that we don’t care about them until that moment comes; we realize that we should have learned them before. Our core elements sit around our question is “how might we determine which information is most important for students to know, how might we make this information available to everyone, how might we publish this knowledge to a public platform, how might we transition from student to capable independent citizens, how might we encourage practical knowledge and contribute positively to the world”. We divided these basic skills to 4 different categories: home management, financial wellness, vehicle awareness, health wellness and communication.   We have asked some “why” questions to understand our problem deeper. These questions were “Why do we postpone learning basic skills?, “Why we can’t survive without handling our own problems?”, and “Why school doesn’t teach students about basic life skills?”.   I would like to ask my classmates, how can we determine which kind of basic skills should we focus on? Which channels would be more effective to deal with this problem? Is there a “fun” way to make people learn these skills? How can we make people willing to learn basic skills in life?   I’m looking forward to your comments!
        Manage Discussion Entry
        • Go To Topic
        • Edit
        • Delete
        • Open in SpeedGrader

        Our “how might we?” question is “How might we teach basic life skills to ensure independence and increase people’s awareness on this topic?”

         

        Think about your life in high school. You are living with your family, you don’t have great responsibilities, your mom cooks for you and your dad pays your bills. Then, you start to college. You move to a home with your friends. You have to do your own laundry, you have to make your bed, you have to pay your bills, you have to set a bank account, you have to cook yourself.

         

        When we think about these basic life skills, we see that we don’t care about them until that moment comes; we realize that we should have learned them before. Our core elements sit around our question is “how might we determine which information is most important for students to know, how might we make this information available to everyone, how might we publish this knowledge to a public platform, how might we transition from student to capable independent citizens, how might we encourage practical knowledge and contribute positively to the world”. We divided these basic skills to 4 different categories: home management, financial wellness, vehicle awareness, health wellness and communication.

         

        We have asked some “why” questions to understand our problem deeper. These questions were “Why do we postpone learning basic skills?, “Why we can’t survive without handling our own problems?”, and “Why school doesn’t teach students about basic life skills?”.

         

        I would like to ask my classmates, how can we determine which kind of basic skills should we focus on? Which channels would be more effective to deal with this problem? Is there a “fun” way to make people learn these skills? How can we make people willing to learn basic skills in life?

         

        I’m looking forward to your comments!

        Reply Reply to Comment
        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
         
          Attach
          Cancel
          • Collapse Subdiscussion Zoe Randolph

            Zoe Randolph

            Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 6:05pm
            Hi Lal, I think your group's "how might we" is really important. I was thinking of your first question, "why do we postpone learning basic skills?" In my opinion, I don't think we postpone learning basic skills. I think what a "basic skill" is, changes as we get older. Paying taxes or managing a bank account isn't necessary for a child in elementary school. Learning how to read, write, or count is more important. As we grow older we need to learn more and more how to become self-efficient. These "basic" skills are necessary for college students and adults, but not children. But I think there should be an intro class when students get to college to help them better adjust into self-sufficiency. 
            Manage Discussion Entry
            • Go To Parent
            • Edit
            • Delete
            • Open in SpeedGrader

            Hi Lal,

            I think your group's "how might we" is really important. I was thinking of your first question, "why do we postpone learning basic skills?" In my opinion, I don't think we postpone learning basic skills. I think what a "basic skill" is, changes as we get older. Paying taxes or managing a bank account isn't necessary for a child in elementary school. Learning how to read, write, or count is more important. As we grow older we need to learn more and more how to become self-efficient. These "basic" skills are necessary for college students and adults, but not children. But I think there should be an intro class when students get to college to help them better adjust into self-sufficiency.

              • Collapse Subdiscussion Marina Fraile-Romero

                Marina Fraile-Romero

                Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 10:23pm
                Hey Lal! Thank you for your post! The problem you try to fix is really interesting and most of college students feel quite lost at some point in their life as students. So, there is no doubt that it would be very useful to have something helping with these issues. In my opinion, a way to make people enjoy learning these kind of basic skills could be by using social media content. As we discussed in class, stories engage people, and even more for students. In that sense, creating videos which teach these basic issues while something else is going on, could be a good way to think about engaging your target and empathizing with them.
                Manage Discussion Entry
                • Go To Parent
                • Edit
                • Delete
                • Open in SpeedGrader

                Hey Lal!

                Thank you for your post!

                The problem you try to fix is really interesting and most of college students feel quite lost at some point in their life as students. So, there is no doubt that it would be very useful to have something helping with these issues.

                In my opinion, a way to make people enjoy learning these kind of basic skills could be by using social media content. As we discussed in class, stories engage people, and even more for students. In that sense, creating videos which teach these basic issues while something else is going on, could be a good way to think about engaging your target and empathizing with them.

                  • Collapse Subdiscussion KATE SIMONDS

                    KATE SIMONDS

                    Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 10:27pm
                    Hi Lal! First of all, I really like your how might we statement! I think independence is something that should be much more valuable in society. It seems absolutely crazy that even at a school like Berkeley, so many of us lack so many basic life skills (me included!).  I don't know why these skills are postponed- but maybe because they don't really fit into one specific class? Our modern education system is formed around classes that can be tested on, and life isn't really something you can test with a scantron. Maybe that's why these skills have been pushed out. 
                    Manage Discussion Entry
                    • Go To Parent
                    • Edit
                    • Delete
                    • Open in SpeedGrader

                    Hi Lal! First of all, I really like your how might we statement! I think independence is something that should be much more valuable in society. It seems absolutely crazy that even at a school like Berkeley, so many of us lack so many basic life skills (me included!). 

                    I don't know why these skills are postponed- but maybe because they don't really fit into one specific class? Our modern education system is formed around classes that can be tested on, and life isn't really something you can test with a scantron. Maybe that's why these skills have been pushed out.

                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Samantha Holder

                        Samantha Holder

                        Mar 14, 2017 Mar 14 at 12:55am
                        Hey Lal, thanks for the great response and I'm excited that your team is tackling such a relevant issue. In response to your question of "How can we determine which kind of basic skills should we focus on?," one thing I would recommend is shadowing your target consumers. While user testing/interviews would be helpful, it's hard to determine off the top of your head what basic skills you might be lacking. Additionally, some people might not even realize they are lacking certain, "adult skills." As a preliminary form of research, it might be fun to shadow a friend for a few hours to see how they tackle simple day-to-day things. You might find that they walk everywhere because they never picked up the skill of using public transportation or you might notice that they never call their parents because they never learned how to properly make phone calls. While there are obvious life skills that many millennials are lacking such as how to make dinner without a microwave and how to change a tire, I'm interested to see if you find any other important skills that millennials seem to be collectively lacking. Thanks!
                        Manage Discussion Entry
                        • Go To Parent
                        • Edit
                        • Delete
                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                        Hey Lal, thanks for the great response and I'm excited that your team is tackling such a relevant issue. In response to your question of "How can we determine which kind of basic skills should we focus on?," one thing I would recommend is shadowing your target consumers. While user testing/interviews would be helpful, it's hard to determine off the top of your head what basic skills you might be lacking. Additionally, some people might not even realize they are lacking certain, "adult skills." As a preliminary form of research, it might be fun to shadow a friend for a few hours to see how they tackle simple day-to-day things. You might find that they walk everywhere because they never picked up the skill of using public transportation or you might notice that they never call their parents because they never learned how to properly make phone calls. While there are obvious life skills that many millennials are lacking such as how to make dinner without a microwave and how to change a tire, I'm interested to see if you find any other important skills that millennials seem to be collectively lacking. Thanks!

                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Manuel Gonzalez

                            Manuel Gonzalez

                            Mar 14, 2017 Mar 14 at 12:58am
                            Hi Lal, I think your group is answering a very important question that is relevant to almost everyone. It's weird to think about the teaching of these kinds of skills. it's something that isn't formally learned, but that everyone still learns at some point. I think there should be a system in place that makes it so that the introduction to these kinds of skills isn't delayed or interfere with people's lives. In regards to your first question, I think cooking is definitely something to explore. It astounds me how many people eat junk on a daily basis simply because they don't know how to cook and don't have someone experienced cook for them. teaching people basic recipes that can hep them sustain a healthy diet is something to look into, aside from taxes and car maintenance.

                            Hi Lal, I think your group is answering a very important question that is relevant to almost everyone. I think there should be a system in place that makes it so that the introduction to these kinds of skills isn't delayed or interfere with people's lives. In regards to your first question, I think cooking is definitely something to explore. It astounds me how many people eat junk on a daily basis simply because they don't know how to cook and don't have someone experienced cook for them. teaching people basic recipes that can hep them sustain a healthy diet is something to look into, aside from taxes and car maintenance.

                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion Sarah Alsamman

                                    Sarah Alsamman

                                    Mar 16, 2017 Mar 16 at 12:25am
                                    Hi Lal! So your groups project has been on my mind lately because I recently had some car problems and literally had no idea what to do and called my Dad 1000 times for help. I think that we don't learn these life skills because there is a lack of urgency around them. As a society our frame of what education entails is very outlined and it DOES NOT include life skills. I recently read an article that in struggling classrooms when the teacher introduced life skills training as part of the curriculum students did better in their other non-life skills work because the life skills training contextualized their learning (I will try to find and share with you). I think that a societal frameshift on what we view as valuable education is needed. 
                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                    • Go To Parent
                                    • Edit
                                    • Delete
                                    • Open in SpeedGrader

                                    Hi Lal!

                                    So your groups project has been on my mind lately because I recently had some car problems and literally had no idea what to do and called my Dad 1000 times for help. I think that we don't learn these life skills because there is a lack of urgency around them. As a society our frame of what education entails is very outlined and it DOES NOT include life skills. I recently read an article that in struggling classrooms when the teacher introduced life skills training as part of the curriculum students did better in their other non-life skills work because the life skills training contextualized their learning (I will try to find and share with you). I think that a societal frameshift on what we view as valuable education is needed.

                                        Collapse Subdiscussion Zoe Randolph

                                        Zoe Randolph

                                        Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 5:56pm
                                        My team's how might we is "how might we help individuals to express themselves through accessible, high quality, sustainable and affordable unique clothing?" Fashion has always been a unique form of self- expression as well as a way to pinpoint a time in history. People choose clothes often by what's portrayed in the media and what others are wearing around them. "Trends" often hide self- expression and individuality. I love art and I love that fashion is becoming more of a work of art. Fashion Designer Alexander McQueen was one of the first designers to be recognized and celebrated as an artist. What my group wants to do is to use art as a way of helping other people find self-expression.  I liked the reading, "Framing and re-framing: Core skills for a problem-filled world" because it focused on finding the right solution for a problem. The example it used was the bridge. A bridge is useful if your problem is getting something heavy to the other side. However, an email or a phone call is quicker, more efficient solution if you're trying to relay a bit of information.  One part of the reading states that the "ability to put yourself in another’s shoes is critical to framing problems so that they can be solved." For our group's solution, we need to empathize with our target market in order to develop a consumer "want" or "need."Our project is to essentially speak for someone else so it's critical for us to do so accurately.  In my opinion, fashion has always been political is some sense. It either has represented freedom or lack thereof. During the women's march, some women wore "pussyhats" to protest Trump and his misogynistic remarks. How do we keep our project from being political? Or is that something we want to help people, especially Berkeley students, express?
                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                        • Go To Topic
                                        • Edit
                                        • Delete
                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                        My team's how might we is "how might we help individuals to express themselves through accessible, high quality, sustainable and affordable unique clothing?" Fashion has always been a unique form of self- expression as well as a way to pinpoint a time in history. People choose clothes often by what's portrayed in the media and what others are wearing around them. "Trends" often hide self- expression and individuality. I love art and I love that fashion is becoming more of a work of art. Fashion Designer Alexander McQueen was one of the first designers to be recognized and celebrated as an artist. What my group wants to do is to use art as a way of helping other people find self-expression. 

                                        I liked the reading, "Framing and re-framing: Core skills for a problem-filled world" because it focused on finding the right solution for a problem. The example it used was the bridge. A bridge is useful if your problem is getting something heavy to the other side. However, an email or a phone call is quicker, more efficient solution if you're trying to relay a bit of information. 

                                        One part of the reading states that the "ability to put yourself in another’s shoes is critical to framing problems so that they can be solved." For our group's solution, we need to empathize with our target market in order to develop a consumer "want" or "need."Our project is to essentially speak for someone else so it's critical for us to do so accurately. 

                                        In my opinion, fashion has always been political is some sense. It either has represented freedom or lack thereof. During the women's march, some women wore "pussyhats" to protest Trump and his misogynistic remarks. How do we keep our project from being political? Or is that something we want to help people, especially Berkeley students, express?

                                        Edited by Zoe Randolph on Mar 13 at 5:59pm

                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Marina Fraile-Romero

                                            Marina Fraile-Romero

                                            Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 10:17pm
                                            Hey Zoe! Thank you for you comment! I really like fashion and I love your how might we question. But related to your question, I feel that by providing accessible, high quality, sustainable and affordable unique clothing, you are creating a kind of movement or expression for people choosing you what you offers.  I believe that you would have a really specific target and one goal which I would suggest for your project could be increasing this target, and so achieving better results and a bigger movement. I do not think that fashion is political, but there is no doubt that it is a way to express feelings and opinions.

                                            Hey Zoe!

                                            Thank you for you comment!

                                            I really like fashion and I love your how might we question. But related to your question, I feel that by providing accessible, high quality, sustainable and affordable unique clothing, you are creating a kind of movement or expression for people choosing you what you offers. 

                                            I believe that you would have a really specific target and one goal which I would suggest for your project could be increasing this target, and so achieving better results and a bigger movement. I do not think that fashion is political, but there is no doubt that it is a way to express feelings and opinions.

                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion DESTINY HWANG

                                                DESTINY HWANG

                                                Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 11:09pm
                                                Hi Zoe, I enjoyed reading your discussion because my father owns a clothing factory in downtown LA, so fashion and clothes have always been like "family" in my life. I agree that individuals express themselves through how they dress up and what kind of clothes they wear. I was curious by reading your discussion that how is your team going to help people to find their self-expression through fashion. What kind of channels, platform, or methods are you guys going to use to help people? Also, I think you don't have to keep your project from being political because if someone wants to express their political belief by showing how they dress up, then I think you should help them to express their political beliefs. Therefore, I think your project can be political or not political depends on the people whom you help. 
                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                • Go To Parent
                                                • Edit
                                                • Delete
                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                Hi Zoe,

                                                I enjoyed reading your discussion because my father owns a clothing factory in downtown LA, so fashion and clothes have always been like "family" in my life. I agree that individuals express themselves through how they dress up and what kind of clothes they wear. I was curious by reading your discussion that how is your team going to help people to find their self-expression through fashion. What kind of channels, platform, or methods are you guys going to use to help people?

                                                Also, I think you don't have to keep your project from being political because if someone wants to express their political belief by showing how they dress up, then I think you should help them to express their political beliefs. Therefore, I think your project can be political or not political depends on the people whom you help.

                                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion Molly Simon

                                                    Molly Simon

                                                    Mar 14, 2017 Mar 14 at 1:42pm
                                                    Hi Zoe--I find your question very interesting. I guess what you should narrow in on is what kind of expression you are talking about in offering people more affordable clothing. What aspect of their identity do you want people to feel more free to show off? So many aspects of our identites are political, and I think that fashion in general is inevitably political because it is a representation of democracy, of our freedom of speech. However, pushing the envelope through fashion is not something everyone feels comfortable doing.

                                                    Hi Zoe--I find your question very interesting. I guess what you should narrow in on is what kind of expression you are talking about in offering people more affordable clothing. What aspect of their identity do you want people to feel more free to show off? So many aspects of our identites are political, and I think that fashion in general is inevitably political because it is a representation of democracy, of our freedom of speech. However, pushing the envelope through fashion is not something everyone feels comfortable doing.

                                                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Carlos Allende Bres

                                                        Carlos Allende Bres

                                                        Mar 14, 2017 Mar 14 at 5:59pm
                                                        Hi Zoe, I believe there are many ways to express yourself and your points of view. If you do not want to engage in political discourse I would suggest that your clothing designs do as little reference to that as possible. Maybe do a design about the importance of recycling or about freedom of speech (still political but not debatable since its a right). Focus on statements to be made that can't easily relate to politics, or just to actual facts. E.g. "We only have one Earth, lets take care of it".
                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                        • Go To Parent
                                                        • Edit
                                                        • Delete
                                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                        Hi Zoe,

                                                        I believe there are many ways to express yourself and your points of view. If you do not want to engage in political discourse I would suggest that your clothing designs do as little reference to that as possible. Maybe do a design about the importance of recycling or about freedom of speech (still political but not debatable since its a right). Focus on statements to be made that can't easily relate to politics, or just to actual facts. E.g. "We only have one Earth, lets take care of it".

                                                            Samantha Lamos

                                                            Mar 16, 2017 Mar 16 at 1:38pm
                                                            Hi Zoe,       I really enjoyed reading your post, I believe that people are as political as they want to be and given that some people enjoy wearing politically charged clothes while others don't. Honestly I think that whether your clothing line is political or not depends entirely on your original goal. Whether that is to create a line of clothes that represents individuality or one that represents a certain perspective. I feel that since your goal is individuality and self expression, your clothes should represent the opinions and feelings of the wearer, political or not.
                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                            • Go To Parent
                                                            • Edit
                                                            • Delete

                                                            Hi Zoe, 

                                                                 I really enjoyed reading your post, I believe that people are as political as they want to be and given that some people enjoy wearing politically charged clothes while others don't. Honestly I think that whether your clothing line is political or not depends entirely on your original goal. Whether that is to create a line of clothes that represents individuality or one that represents a certain perspective. I feel that since your goal is individuality and self expression, your clothes should represent the opinions and feelings of the wearer, political or not.

                                                                Collapse Subdiscussion Marina Fraile-Romero

                                                                Marina Fraile-Romero

                                                                Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 10:08pm
                                                                Our project's How Might We.. is how might we design a service that contributes to the environment and university by altering buildings.  Architecture, buildings, and infrastructures surround our daily life, and the vast majority of our activities take place or interact with buildings. Moreover, cities are becoming bigger, with more pollution and waste generation. As we all know, seeking and developing environment-friendly initiatives and sustainability projects should be our main common goal in order to save our world. Thus, the motivation behind rebuilding or thinking about a more sustainable design is the huge impact it can produce to the world because any change would affect many activities and the externalities of these, giving us a scaling tool for improvement. Related to the article "Framing and Re-framing" and also to the video about complexity, I feel that the above paragraph is a reflection of it: we found our HMW, which is more specific and concrete, but then we can take a step back, see the overall picture, the overall need, and then redefine our problem and the way to solve it.  As said before, the little changes in our buildings could create a huge impact. Nonetheless, because these changes are also really costly, I would like to ask you which methods or initiatives could we use to get the funding needed?   Thank you so much!
                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                • Go To Topic
                                                                • Edit
                                                                • Delete
                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                Our project's How Might We.. is how might we design a service that contributes to the environment and university by altering buildings. 

                                                                Architecture, buildings, and infrastructures surround our daily life, and the vast majority of our activities take place or interact with buildings. Moreover, cities are becoming bigger, with more pollution and waste generation. As we all know, seeking and developing environment-friendly initiatives and sustainability projects should be our main common goal in order to save our world. Thus, the motivation behind rebuilding or thinking about a more sustainable design is the huge impact it can produce to the world because any change would affect many activities and the externalities of these, giving us a scaling tool for improvement.

                                                                Related to the article "Framing and Re-framing" and also to the video about complexity, I feel that the above paragraph is a reflection of it: we found our HMW, which is more specific and concrete, but then we can take a step back, see the overall picture, the overall need, and then redefine our problem and the way to solve it. 

                                                                As said before, the little changes in our buildings could create a huge impact. Nonetheless, because these changes are also really costly, I would like to ask you which methods or initiatives could we use to get the funding needed?

                                                                 

                                                                Thank you so much!

                                                                Edited by Marina Fraile-Romero on Mar 13 at 10:10pm
                                                                Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                 
                                                                  Attach
                                                                  Cancel
                                                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion KATE SIMONDS

                                                                    KATE SIMONDS

                                                                    Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 10:30pm
                                                                    Hi Marina!  I'm really excited to see where your project goes! I remember reading an article in TIME magazine when I was a kid about a completely eco-friendly house and being so enchanted by it. Now, 15 years later that green house still isn't as common as TIME promised it would be. I'm really looking forward to seeing what your team comes up with! I think a good place to start looking for funding would be private grants from conservation NGOs and local nonprofits!

                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion KATE SIMONDS

                                                                          KATE SIMONDS

                                                                          Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 10:24pm
                                                                          My team's question is "how might we develop a safe space on campus where students can express themselves without restrictions?" I think the key elements of this question are:  A) "Safe"- our project was inspired by the private publicity of restroom stalls and the provocative conversations which often occur.  B) "On campus"- there are plenty of places in the Bay Area to express our creativity, but very few on campus. Of those available to students, they are expensive (such as a Maker's pass at Jacobs Hall), time consuming (art classes or productions), or extremely exclusive. Our campus needs an accessible, inexpensive, and inclusive space.  C) "Without restrictions"- it seems as though the lack of creativity on campus can attributed to the high-pressure culture of this institution. Our team agrees that for the space to be successful in allowing students to express themselves creatively, there must be no restrictions or expectations of the space.  There are two parts of the system that I don't quite understand yet. 1) Why doesn't this space exist already?  2) Since our university is a large publicly-funded school deeply rooted in tradition, is it likely that our project will ever come to fruition or even be taken seriously? 
                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                          • Go To Topic
                                                                          • Edit
                                                                          • Delete
                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                          My team's question is "how might we develop a safe space on campus where students can express themselves without restrictions?"

                                                                          I think the key elements of this question are: 

                                                                          A) "Safe"- our project was inspired by the private publicity of restroom stalls and the provocative conversations which often occur. 

                                                                          B) "On campus"- there are plenty of places in the Bay Area to express our creativity, but very few on campus. Of those available to students, they are expensive (such as a Maker's pass at Jacobs Hall), time consuming (art classes or productions), or extremely exclusive. Our campus needs an accessible, inexpensive, and inclusive space. 

                                                                          C) "Without restrictions"- it seems as though the lack of creativity on campus can attributed to the high-pressure culture of this institution. Our team agrees that for the space to be successful in allowing students to express themselves creatively, there must be no restrictions or expectations of the space. 

                                                                          There are two parts of the system that I don't quite understand yet.

                                                                          1) Why doesn't this space exist already? 

                                                                          2) Since our university is a large publicly-funded school deeply rooted in tradition, is it likely that our project will ever come to fruition or even be taken seriously? 

                                                                          Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                          HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                           
                                                                            Attach
                                                                            Cancel
                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion DESTINY HWANG

                                                                              DESTINY HWANG

                                                                              Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 11:01pm
                                                                              Hi Kate, Your team's topic is very interesting! I live right next to People's park, so safety is one of the greatest issues I have as I live in Berkeley. I think the reason why our campus is not very safe is that the Berkeley area and the campus are open to anyone. Even though we have UCPD and security service on campus, it is still very hard to watch over every part on campus. Anybody can access to most of the buildings on campus, and Berkeley is known for liberal and hippie culture, so I am wondering if keeping campus safe without restriction might be possible.   
                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                              • Go To Parent

                                                                              Hi Kate,

                                                                              Your team's topic is very interesting! I live right next to People's park, so safety is one of the greatest issues I have as I live in Berkeley. I think the reason why our campus is not very safe is that the Berkeley area and the campus are open to anyone. Even though we have UCPD and security service on campus, it is still very hard to watch over every part on campus. Anybody can access to most of the buildings on campus, and Berkeley is known for liberal and hippie culture, so I am wondering if keeping campus safe without restriction might be possible.

                                                                                  Samantha Holder

                                                                                  Mar 14, 2017 Mar 14 at 1:03am
                                                                                  Hey Kate, thanks for the great response and I'm excited that your team is tackling this issue. In response to your first question, I think that while this particular space doesn't exist, there are many spaces similar to this that do. While there are ceramics rooms, music halls, woodworking studios and 3D printers in various parts of campus, all of these art spaces seem to be disconnected and dispersed. Rather than replacing these spaces, it would be interesting if your team could find a way to connect them.
                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                  • Go To Parent
                                                                                  • Edit
                                                                                  • Delete
                                                                                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                  Hey Kate, thanks for the great response and I'm excited that your team is tackling this issue. In response to your first question, I think that while this particular space doesn't exist, there are many spaces similar to this that do. While there are ceramics rooms, music halls, woodworking studios and 3D printers in various parts of campus, all of these art spaces seem to be disconnected and dispersed. Rather than replacing these spaces, it would be interesting if your team could find a way to connect them.

                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Nicola Phillips

                                                                                      Nicola Phillips

                                                                                      Mar 14, 2017 Mar 14 at 8:29pm
                                                                                      I think this sounds like such a good idea! In answer to your first question, I think that sometimes the notion of "space spaces" in general can be stigmatized, and people are often afraid to go against the status quo and step out from the crowd. I also feel as if safe spaces are typically created for a specific group in mind, which inherently excludes those who are not part of that group. So I think that your branding/marketing will be really important, so that all/any students feel as if this is a space for them as much as anyone else. It's inherently difficult to create an environment in which every person there feels comfortable expressing themselves freely and openly, especially in a place with a lot of diversity. I'm really excited to see what you guys come up with!
                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                      • Go To Parent
                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                      I think this sounds like such a good idea! In answer to your first question, I think that sometimes the notion of "space spaces" in general can be stigmatized, and people are often afraid to go against the status quo and step out from the crowd. I also feel as if safe spaces are typically created for a specific group in mind, which inherently excludes those who are not part of that group. So I think that your branding/marketing will be really important, so that all/any students feel as if this is a space for them as much as anyone else. It's inherently difficult to create an environment in which every person there feels comfortable expressing themselves freely and openly, especially in a place with a lot of diversity. I'm really excited to see what you guys come up with!

                                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Stephanie Luna-Lopez

                                                                                          Stephanie Luna-Lopez

                                                                                          Mar 15, 2017 Mar 15 at 7:57pm
                                                                                          Hey Kate! I feel that a creative outlet would be incredibly beneficial for the mental health of students. Perhaps it may be difficult to create a permanent space, but you could definitely try setting something up on Sproul to get a feel for your audience. The 4th and 5th floors of Moffitt seem to be an accessible place where you can go to not only study but also draw and let your mind wander with the glass walls and dry erase markers. So perhaps libraries could be possible locations for the permanent creative space. Whether it gets taken serious or not is hard to predict, but it could be a space that is available during dead week and finals week. Good luck with your project! It's a really good idea!
                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                          • Go To Parent

                                                                                          Hey Kate!

                                                                                          I feel that a creative outlet would be incredibly beneficial for the mental health of students. Perhaps it may be difficult to create a permanent space, but you could definitely try setting something up on Sproul to get a feel for your audience. The 4th and 5th floors of Moffitt seem to be an accessible place where you can go to not only study but also draw and let your mind wander with the glass walls and dry erase markers. So perhaps libraries could be possible locations for the permanent creative space. Whether it gets taken serious or not is hard to predict, but it could be a space that is available during dead week and finals week. Good luck with your project! It's a really good idea!

                                                                                              Mar 16, 2017 Mar 16 at 12:17am
                                                                                              Hi Kate! Super excited by your groups question and project.  I think spaces for expression do exist in many places on campus but they are really inaccessible or exclusive (need makers pass, need keycard access, need to pay hella for art class even though I already pay tuition to go here etc.) which discourages or excludes so many people from participating. I think that making something accessible and welcoming would be very welcomed on campus. However, due to the high-pressure culture on campus I think many haven't had the opportunity to express creatively and feel intimidated by it. It may be cool to consider anonymity in the process, its crazy how when a name or identity isn't attached to a piece so much pressure is removed.

                                                                                              Hi Kate!

                                                                                              Super excited by your groups question and project. 

                                                                                              I think spaces for expression do exist in many places on campus but they are really inaccessible or exclusive (need makers pass, need keycard access, need to pay hella for art class even though I already pay tuition to go here etc.) which discourages or excludes so many people from participating.

                                                                                              I think that making something accessible and welcoming would be very welcomed on campus. However, due to the high-pressure culture on campus I think many haven't had the opportunity to express creatively and feel intimidated by it. It may be cool to consider anonymity in the process, its crazy how when a name or identity isn't attached to a piece so much pressure is removed.

                                                                                                  Francesca Ledesma

                                                                                                  Mar 16, 2017 Mar 16 at 8:30am
                                                                                                  Hi Kate, 1) This space doesn't exist already because people probably take to social media or writing published articles to express their strong opinions. Because Berkeley prides itself on its safe space and its freedom of speech, it's just assumed that this would happen on campus (but I think its not as safe or accepting as we'd like to believe). The number of conversations that I've overheard or engaged in are various. My question for you is that people with strong and often inflexible opinions are more likely to use a platform for expression, so how will you enforce the safe and open-minded aspect of it? 2) Because this is Berkeley, I think any way to express yourself will be support by a portion of, if not the whole, student body! If it was an art exhibit or a more artistic platform, then more people would accept it.
                                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                  • Go To Parent

                                                                                                  Hi Kate,

                                                                                                  1) This space doesn't exist already because people probably take to social media or writing published articles to express their strong opinions. Because Berkeley prides itself on its safe space and its freedom of speech, it's just assumed that this would happen on campus (but I think its not as safe or accepting as we'd like to believe). The number of conversations that I've overheard or engaged in are various. My question for you is that people with strong and often inflexible opinions are more likely to use a platform for expression, so how will you enforce the safe and open-minded aspect of it?

                                                                                                  2) Because this is Berkeley, I think any way to express yourself will be support by a portion of, if not the whole, student body! If it was an art exhibit or a more artistic platform, then more people would accept it.

                                                                                                      • Collapse Subdiscussion DESTINY HWANG

                                                                                                        DESTINY HWANG

                                                                                                        Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 10:44pm
                                                                                                        How might we create an app/service/platform to provide all kinds of information about planning a day out in San Francisco? When people travel to San Francisco, everyone goes to Golden Gate Bridge, Fishermen's Wharf, and Union Square. These are very famous spots for tourists, and you should visit these places when you come to San Francisco. However, there are tons of other places you should definitely visit in San Francisco.  Many people google and search other sources for planning a travel in San Francisco, but even those search engines only recommend the places I mentioned earlier.   So, we want to create a service that has all the information about San Francisco such as places to go, places to eat, places where clean restrooms are, places you shouldn't walk, etc. Then the key elements for my team's HMW questions are... information, credibility, providing a differentiated service, reviews from users. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- my questions, 1. how can we create a service different from Yelp, timeout, and many other travel companies? 2. Should we target our users at travelers or local people? 
                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                        • Go To Topic
                                                                                                        • Edit
                                                                                                        • Delete
                                                                                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                        How might we create an app/service/platform to provide all kinds of information about planning a day out in San Francisco?

                                                                                                        When people travel to San Francisco, everyone goes to Golden Gate Bridge, Fishermen's Wharf, and Union Square. These are very famous spots for tourists, and you should visit these places when you come to San Francisco. However, there are tons of other places you should definitely visit in San Francisco. 

                                                                                                        Many people google and search other sources for planning a travel in San Francisco, but even those search engines only recommend the places I mentioned earlier.  

                                                                                                        So, we want to create a service that has all the information about San Francisco such as places to go, places to eat, places where clean restrooms are, places you shouldn't walk, etc.

                                                                                                        Then the key elements for my team's HMW questions are...

                                                                                                        information, credibility, providing a differentiated service, reviews from users.

                                                                                                        --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

                                                                                                        my questions,

                                                                                                        1. how can we create a service different from Yelp, timeout, and many other travel companies?

                                                                                                        2. Should we target our users at travelers or local people? 

                                                                                                        Edited by DESTINY HWANG on Mar 13 at 10:57pm

I think creating an app that would better help us navigate the city with greater ease would be helpful. We live in such an amazing place and I would love if tourists got to experience how wonderful it is to live here. I also think you should target people as travelers and locals.

I think creating an app that would better help us navigate the city with greater ease would be helpful. We live in such an amazing place and I would love if tourists got to experience how wonderful it is to live here. I also think you should target people as travelers and locals.

Also you can do a research or survey among Berkeley students. The problem you are addressing is hard but I think it will be fun to work on it!

                                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Carlos Allende Bres

                                                                                                                            Carlos Allende Bres

                                                                                                                            Mar 14, 2017 Mar 14 at 6:03pm
                                                                                                                            Hi Destiny, One very important thing about tourists is that most of them want an "authentic" experience. Meaning, that maybe they will get to see and cross the Golden Gate, but maybe they also want to experience what would it be to "live" there. You might want to look into recommendations from people currently living in SF and ask them about their favorite unknown, non-tourist spots in the city. That could go a long way to differentiate youselves from other travel companies that might not have this information... yet.
                                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                            • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                            • Edit
                                                                                                                            • Delete
                                                                                                                            • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                            Hi Destiny,

                                                                                                                            One very important thing about tourists is that most of them want an "authentic" experience. Meaning, that maybe they will get to see and cross the Golden Gate, but maybe they also want to experience what would it be to "live" there. You might want to look into recommendations from people currently living in SF and ask them about their favorite unknown, non-tourist spots in the city. That could go a long way to differentiate youselves from other travel companies that might not have this information... yet.

                                                                                                                            HTML Editor Rich Content Editor

                                                                                                                              Cancel
                                                                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Nicola Phillips

                                                                                                                                Nicola Phillips

                                                                                                                                Mar 14, 2017 Mar 14 at 8:24pm
                                                                                                                                I really like your group's idea! In answer to your two questions, I think you could address your first question through your second. I think targeting travelers would be a more profitable market, since when people are tourists in an area they typically want to explore more. But that's not to say that locals should be excluded. Rather, I think it'd be interesting to create an app that would allow for a dialogue between locals and tourists—kind of like AirBnb but for traveling/exploring an area. That would definitely help differentiate your product, because it's much more personal to get individual prospective and see exactly who is recommending what. So people who live in the area could share their favorite places to eat/hike/whatever. People visiting could narrow their preferences to see specific types of activities/types of places/etc.
                                                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                I really like your group's idea! In answer to your two questions, I think you could address your first question through your second. I think targeting travelers would be a more profitable market, since when people are tourists in an area they typically want to explore more. But that's not to say that locals should be excluded. Rather, I think it'd be interesting to create an app that would allow for a dialogue between locals and tourists—kind of like AirBnb but for traveling/exploring an area. That would definitely help differentiate your product, because it's much more personal to get individual prospective and see exactly who is recommending what. So people who live in the area could share their favorite places to eat/hike/whatever. People visiting could narrow their preferences to see specific types of activities/types of places/etc.
