                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Hi so just right off of the top of the prompt my groups "how might we" is How might we revolutionize the modern workout with the truth? As we went through the mapping exercise that my group did in class we made a very basic how might we map on our poster board that looks nothing like the complex USA task force map talked about in the video. This is partly due to the limited time that we put into the project but even what we designed was large enough to scare someone away. I think something that has been useful in our class is the ability to take everyones unique problem solving brains. From day one we have been trying to figure out our own "problem cycle" (or whatever the actual term is) and Sara's article really breaks down the ideas and thinkings behind it. Our group knows that creating a business or an MVP will be difficult and complex but the best way for us to tackle the project is letting all of our brains think outside the box to really make the best product we can.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Two questions I need clarity with are:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1) In reference to the scientist studying sleeping patterns in the Talking to Humans reading, the example really broke the question down to its most basic root. It is good to really dive deep into problems but should all simple problems in life be broken down that far? 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          2) What are some examples where breaking down a life problem to its root could over complicate things and make your solution worse off?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Attach
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Jake Trambert

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Jake Trambert

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Mar 16, 2017 Mar 16 at 12:25pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Matt,  I agree with the implication of your first question, asking weather or not simple problems can/should be broken down further than their current level of simplicity. I think that there definetly exists a level at which problems should be left as is; in breaking down a problem past a point of genuine simplicity, I believe you begin to counteract the effect, and in essence begin to re-complicate the problem in question.  As an example for a problem that would fit this description, consider a simple problem; an oven that over heats, and burns food as a result. Breaking this problem down simply, you could address it by saying something like 'the pilot light is faulty, and thus too much gas is allowed into into the ignition, causing the oven to heat up much faster than usual.' Break it down to ' the pilot light it faulty.' To take it any further than this, you would need to dive into the explanation of the certain mechanics behind the design of the pilot light, identify which part has malfunctioned and why, which would open an entirely new plot of questioning, shattering you simple and original address of the problem 'the pilot light is faulty, so the oven has ben burning our food.' 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Matt, 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I agree with the implication of your first question, asking weather or not simple problems can/should be broken down further than their current level of simplicity. I think that there definetly exists a level at which problems should be left as is; in breaking down a problem past a point of genuine simplicity, I believe you begin to counteract the effect, and in essence begin to re-complicate the problem in question. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              As an example for a problem that would fit this description, consider a simple problem; an oven that over heats, and burns food as a result. Breaking this problem down simply, you could address it by saying something like 'the pilot light is faulty, and thus too much gas is allowed into into the ignition, causing the oven to heat up much faster than usual.' Break it down to ' the pilot light it faulty.' To take it any further than this, you would need to dive into the explanation of the certain mechanics behind the design of the pilot light, identify which part has malfunctioned and why, which would open an entirely new plot of questioning, shattering you simple and original address of the problem 'the pilot light is faulty, so the oven has ben burning our food.' 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Attach
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Jake Trambert

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Jake Trambert

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Mar 16, 2017 Mar 16 at 12:17pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Our question: How might we design a service that contributes to the environment as well as the university by sustainable altering buildings around campus?   Although this may seem like a pretty directly connected system, in reality, stepping to the 2nd or 3rd degree can take you very very far away from our problem space, but still encapsulate the core elements crucial to the success of our project. One of these systems rests in the element of creativity that will in essence determine the failure or success of our project. Since our approach will be based in sustainable renovation, and now a complete remodel, our solutions are going to have to rely on incredibly innovative, often times rarely implemented techniques that will both ensure the individual success as a project as well as distinguish our approach as a business. Through this extensive degree, our system connects to innovative sustainable approaches all across the board; from elements of window design, orientation of buildings, monetized excess recourse deals shared between buildings, etc; this is the area that will take us farthest in the system from our initial HMW. In addition, there is the idea of facilitation; all of the various steps we will need to go through in order to get each our plans implemented and approved. Going from the initial level of building owners, campus administration, city ordinances, and etc., it will also be crucial to include regular tenents/workers of the building, those who contributed to its initial construction, professors and students, as well as the campus community as a whole (in context with the sustainable renovation of a campus building). These are the two most crucial elements around which I believe our system is based, and it will only be through the successful address and execution of these fronts that we will be able to find success in our project/as a business. I found the visual representation of the connections between systems in the ‘Simplifying Complexity’ talk to be very inspiring; I think the node model of representation resounds heavily with the representation of the ambitions and goals of our project, and will serve as a very important lesson in defining what really matters, and what we need to focus on most in our address. There are still a couple questions I have about our system that I have been unable to answer; although it was promoted in the Ted Talk that the only degrees that truly matter are the 1st, 2nd, and sometimes 3rd, is this always the case? Although I believe that they are the most important, I think the validity of this claim can really depend on the project/idea in mind. In other words, how do we know when we have addressed the most we can, in terms of elements/problems within a system?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Our question: How might we design a service that contributes to the environment as well as the university by sustainable altering buildings around campus?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Although this may seem like a pretty directly connected system, in reality, stepping to the 2nd or 3rd degree can take you very very far away from our problem space, but still encapsulate the core elements crucial to the success of our project. One of these systems rests in the element of creativity that will in essence determine the failure or success of our project. Since our approach will be based in sustainable renovation, and now a complete remodel, our solutions are going to have to rely on incredibly innovative, often times rarely implemented techniques that will both ensure the individual success as a project as well as distinguish our approach as a business. Through this extensive degree, our system connects to innovative sustainable approaches all across the board; from elements of window design, orientation of buildings, monetized excess recourse deals shared between buildings, etc; this is the area that will take us farthest in the system from our initial HMW. In addition, there is the idea of facilitation; all of the various steps we will need to go through in order to get each our plans implemented and approved. Going from the initial level of building owners, campus administration, city ordinances, and etc., it will also be crucial to include regular tenents/workers of the building, those who contributed to its initial construction, professors and students, as well as the campus community as a whole (in context with the sustainable renovation of a campus building). These are the two most crucial elements around which I believe our system is based, and it will only be through the successful address and execution of these fronts that we will be able to find success in our project/as a business. I found the visual representation of the connections between systems in the ‘Simplifying Complexity’ talk to be very inspiring; I think the node model of representation resounds heavily with the representation of the ambitions and goals of our project, and will serve as a very important lesson in defining what really matters, and what we need to focus on most in our address.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                There are still a couple questions I have about our system that I have been unable to answer; although it was promoted in the Ted Talk that the only degrees that truly matter are the 1st, 2nd, and sometimes 3rd, is this always the case? Although I believe that they are the most important, I think the validity of this claim can really depend on the project/idea in mind. In other words, how do we know when we have addressed the most we can, in terms of elements/problems within a system?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Reply Reply to Comment

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Cancel

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Justin Chen

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Mar 16, 2017 Mar 16 at 1:24pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Hi Jake, Thanks for your response. I think the example given in the TED talk was just a general idea of how to manage complexity - as you said, there are many different ways and it's not always beneficial to look at the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd degrees of seperation. As for your second question, I'm also not sure how to answer it well. I think that most people just take a step back and eyeball it, but it definitely is a complex issue.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Hi Jake,

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Thanks for your response. I think the example given in the TED talk was just a general idea of how to manage complexity - as you said, there are many different ways and it's not always beneficial to look at the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd degrees of seperation. As for your second question, I'm also not sure how to answer it well. I think that most people just take a step back and eyeball it, but it definitely is a complex issue.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion RICHARD WONG

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      RICHARD WONG

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Mar 16, 2017 Mar 16 at 12:38pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      HOW MIGHT WE HELP INDIVIDUALS EXPRESS THEMSELVES THROUGH ACCESSIBLE, HIGH QUALITY, SUSTAINABLE AND UNIQUE CLOTHING?         I think the most core elements my own problem system sits around the solutions we, as a group, are trying are just figuring out right now. We came  into the project obviously very excited, but we found some problems almost immediately. Because we want to make sustainable, yet also fashionable clothing, one of main problems is concerned with pricing. How are we, as a company going to approach this kind of problem? Does sustainability mean increased cost for the benefit we are trying to include? Sustainability is one our core elements when understanding our problem scope, along with another -- our approach to the company's fashion philosophy.  Yes, our fashion can be somewhat sustainable, but in the future, will our product come from somewhere environmentally and morally justified? We hope that our materials/fabrics/labor in our final product don't come from morally comprehensible places.          When I think about my problem of design vs. sustainability vs. cost, I imagine a triangle that I must learn to balance and see what to give or compromise with.    1. Would my classmates personally prefer to buy clothes that cost more, but are environmentally more sustainable? 2. When does cost of clothing/material become too much before sustainability is sacrificed for convenience?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      HOW MIGHT WE HELP INDIVIDUALS EXPRESS THEMSELVES THROUGH ACCESSIBLE, HIGH QUALITY, SUSTAINABLE AND UNIQUE CLOTHING?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I think the most core elements my own problem system sits around the solutions we, as a group, are trying are just figuring out right now. We came  into the project obviously very excited, but we found some problems almost immediately. Because we want to make sustainable, yet also fashionable clothing, one of main problems is concerned with pricing. How are we, as a company going to approach this kind of problem? Does sustainability mean increased cost for the benefit we are trying to include? Sustainability is one our core elements when understanding our problem scope, along with another -- our approach to the company's fashion philosophy.  Yes, our fashion can be somewhat sustainable, but in the future, will our product come from somewhere environmentally and morally justified? We hope that our materials/fabrics/labor in our final product don't come from morally comprehensible places. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              When I think about my problem of design vs. sustainability vs. cost, I imagine a triangle that I must learn to balance and see what to give or compromise with. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      1. Would my classmates personally prefer to buy clothes that cost more, but are environmentally more sustainable?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      2. When does cost of clothing/material become too much before sustainability is sacrificed for convenience?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Attach
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Justin Chen

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Justin Chen

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Mar 16, 2017 Mar 16 at 1:20pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Hi Richard, Thanks for your response. For both questions, I think the best way to find out the answer is to do some market research and find the equilibrium point between cost and sustainability/quality/convenience/fashion. Also looking at the price points of existing sustainable brands (Patagonia, Everlane, etc.) would give you a general idea.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Hi Richard,

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Thanks for your response. For both questions, I think the best way to find out the answer is to do some market research and find the equilibrium point between cost and sustainability/quality/convenience/fashion. Also looking at the price points of existing sustainable brands (Patagonia, Everlane, etc.) would give you a general idea.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Reed Jones

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Mar 16, 2017 Mar 16 at 1:29pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Hi Richard Thanks for your post. I agree with Justin's response that the best way to go about answering this question is to do market research. I personally would be willing to pay more if I knew that the clothes I were buying were more environmentally friendly. However, researching the market for these products may inform you differently.
